newsitem.title: GERMANY: Berlin selling BEWAG because it is broke - minister.
newsitem.headline: Berlin selling BEWAG because it is broke - minister.

text.p: Berlin is selling a majority stake in its power utility Berliner Kraft und Licht AG (BEWAG) because the city is nearly bankrupt and needs the money, Berlin's environmental minister Peter Strieder said on Tuesday.
Strieder, the Senator for the Environment, said in an interview with InfoRadio in Berlin that the city was broke because the federal government was failing to live up to its obligations.

"BEWAG is being sold primarily because the city is bankrupt or nearly bankrupt because the federal government has left us standing in the rain," Strieder said. "It is at the point where we don't really know how we are going to finance the future."
The city is expected to announce later on Tuesday that it has reached an agreement with a German-U.S. consortium to sell its 50.8 percent stake in BEWAG for 2.9 billion marks.
The stake was expected to be sold to German utility groups VIAG AG and Veba AG and U.S. utility Southern Co. Veba and VIAG each currently hold a 10 percent stake in BEWAG.

The deal is expected to give Atlanta-based Southern, one of the largest utilities in the United States, a 23.6 percent stake in the utility, while Veba and VIAG will also both raise their individual stakes to 23.6 percent.
Berlin's city-state parliament was expected to approve the deal on Tuesday.
Germany's federal cartel office has already expressed an opinion that it was against Veba raising its stake in BEWAG, saying its stake would be too extensive.
But German media reports have said Southern was expected to be formally in charge of the commercial management of BEWAG although all decisions would be reached jointly.
